titleInfo.title: Tennessee farm and home science, progress report 152, October - December 1989

mods.abstract: Quarterly newsletter from Knoxville, Tennessee, covering farming and home economics.
mods.tableOfContents: Early symbiotic events leading to nodulation control in legumes - Gifts and grants - Visitor use- value of the University of Tennessee arboretum - Hessian fly on wheat in Tennessee - Yields of irrigated soybeans as affected by row spacing - Soil erosion and related water quality - Computerized kiln research at the University of Tennessee - Derived demand for N, P2O5, and K2O applied to soybeans in Tennessee and the aggregate United States - Osmoregulation in plant roots - Snap bean cultivar trials, 1986-87

originInfo.publisher: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Agricultural Extension Service

mods.note: Digitized with support from a Project Ceres grant. Project Ceres is a collaboration between the United States Agricultural Information Network (USAIN), the Agriculture Network Information Collaborative (AgNIC) and the Center for Research Libraries (CRL) to support ongoing preservation and digitization of collections in the field of agriculture.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
